title: Automated material-aware BIM generation using deep learning for comprehensive indoor element reconstruction
highlights: An automated Scan-to-BIM framework is proposed that integrates deep learning-based geometry and material analysis.
An enhanced instance segmentation network is developed to improve object identification in complex indoor environments.
An accurate 3D BIM modeling workflow is created that reconstructs space-forming and space-occupying elements while preserving key attributes.

A deep learning-based material classification model is developed, and a Revit-based algorithm is introduced for automatic 3D modeling and property assignment.AbstractAutomating 3D reconstruction ofindoor environmentsis essential for scene understanding inBuilding Information Modeling(BIM). This paper addresses the challenge of integrating geometric and material attributes in scan-to-BIM processes. A deep learning-based framework is developed to automatically extract and integrate geometric and material attributes from point clouds, incorporating an enhanced instance segmentation network, a material classification model, and an automated BIM integration workflow for accurate indoor modeling. The proposed framework reconstructs accurate 3D BIM models of space-forming and space-occupying elements while preserving key attributes. Experimental results show significant improvements in instance segmentation accuracy, with reconstructed 3D BIM models achieving over 98 %correctnessandcompleteness, while the material classification model attains a point-based weightedF1−scoreof 0.973 and an object-based accuracy of 94.70 %. These findings advance automated BIM generation, enhancingbuilding planning, asset management, andsustainable designwhile inspiring further developments in scan-to-BIM automation.
abstract: Automating 3D reconstruction ofindoor environmentsis essential for scene understanding inBuilding Information Modeling(BIM). This paper addresses the challenge of integrating geometric and material attributes in scan-to-BIM processes. A deep learning-based framework is developed to automatically extract and integrate geometric and material attributes from point clouds, incorporating an enhanced instance segmentation network, a material classification model, and an automated BIM integration workflow for accurate indoor modeling. The proposed framework reconstructs accurate 3D BIM models of space-forming and space-occupying elements while preserving key attributes. Experimental results show significant improvements in instance segmentation accuracy, with reconstructed 3D BIM models achieving over 98 %correctnessandcompleteness, while the material classification model attains a point-based weightedF1−scoreof 0.973 and an object-based accuracy of 94.70 %. These findings advance automated BIM generation, enhancingbuilding planning, asset management, andsustainable designwhile inspiring further developments in scan-to-BIM automation.

items: An improved instance segmentation network based on deep learning is presented to enhance the identification of indoor objects for processing the 3D point clouds.
An accurate and effective workflow is developed to reconstruct precise 3D BIM models of indoor space-forming and space-occupying objects, preserving their geometric and material characteristics.
An effective material classification deep learning model is introduced based on point cloud coordinates, raw colors, object labels, and intensity features.
An algorithm for automatic 3D BIM modeling of indoor elements with comprehensive property integration is implemented in the Revit platform.

sections.title: 3.6. Automatic 3D BIM modeling of elements with material attributes
4. Results and discussion

items: a)APrepresents the average precision values across various recall levels, providing an equitable assessment of a model's ability to detect and correctly segment instances. As formulated in Eq.10, this metric summarizes the precision-recall curve into a single value. The higher theAPAP50, the better the model correctly identifies and segments instances.

b)AP50refers to the average precision calculated by considering only predictions with anIOUof 50 % or more. As specified by Eq.11,IOUis a standard metric for assessing the overlap between the ground truth and the predicted segmentation bounding boxes.

c)Prec50calculates the proportion of true positive predictions among all positive predictions at anIOUthreshold of 50 %, as detailed in Eq.12, indicating the model precision with a 50 % overlap requirement between predicted and actual regions.
d)Rec50, as defined in Eq.13, measures the proportion of true positive predictions relative to the total number of ground truth instances at anIOUthreshold of 50 %.

content: Table 1.Quantitative Evaluationof Instance Segmentation Models Based on Standard Metrics.

items: a)APrepresents the average precision values across various recall levels, providing an equitable assessment of a model's ability to detect and correctly segment instances. As formulated in Eq.10, this metric summarizes the precision-recall curve into a single value. The higher theAPAP50, the better the model correctly identifies and segments instances.

b)AP50refers to the average precision calculated by considering only predictions with anIOUof 50 % or more. As specified by Eq.11,IOUis a standard metric for assessing the overlap between the ground truth and the predicted segmentation bounding boxes.

c)Prec50calculates the proportion of true positive predictions among all positive predictions at anIOUthreshold of 50 %, as detailed in Eq.12, indicating the model precision with a 50 % overlap requirement between predicted and actual regions.
d)Rec50, as defined in Eq.13, measures the proportion of true positive predictions relative to the total number of ground truth instances at anIOUthreshold of 50 %.
